snippet.textDisplay: Haunted House for the Wii. Not the best, but I still have a lot of fun playing it. Some pretty clever pop culture references in it, too, such as Evil Dead, Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, Edward Scissorhands, Lord of the Rings, and more. Hell, there are even CLUE references.
snippet.textOriginal: Haunted House for the Wii. Not the best, but I still have a lot of fun playing it. Some pretty clever pop culture references in it, too, such as Evil Dead, Nightmare on Elm Street, Friday the 13th, Edward Scissorhands, Lord of the Rings, and more. Hell, there are even CLUE references.

snippet.textDisplay: I love, love, love the buildup in this compilation.  One minute you start off listening to a catchy 8-bit tune, the next its turned into a rock piece, all without ever noticing the transitions.

snippet.textDisplay: Friday the 13th.  I can't remember if I eventually managed to actually beat it or not, but it was certainly pretty creepy at the time.  Castlevania II was an early, and more memorable 'horror' game, and one of the first "open-world-ish" game that I actually managed to finish (with perhaps a bit of help from Nintendo Power, but I was still proud of it at the time).
snippet.textOriginal: Friday the 13th.  I can't remember if I eventually managed to actually beat it or not, but it was certainly pretty creepy at the time.  Castlevania II was an early, and more memorable 'horror' game, and one of the first "open-world-ish" game that I actually managed to finish (with perhaps a bit of help from Nintendo Power, but I was still proud of it at the time).

snippet.textDisplay:
There's a Castlevania easter egg and Vampire Killer song in Contra - Hard Cops. Best Contra game IMO - the song is called "Contra Hard Corps OST - Simon 1994rd"

Somehow I didn't notice this until later on when I played this game on my genesis(I don't think I was aware that Konami made both games back then). It's pretty obvious it's from Castlevania when you see it, it was a boss with a whip.
snippet.textOriginal:
There's a Castlevania easter egg and Vampire Killer song in Contra - Hard Cops. Best Contra game IMO - the song is called "Contra Hard Corps OST - Simon 1994rd"

Somehow I didn't notice this until later on when I played this game on my genesis(I don't think I was aware that Konami made both games back then). It's pretty obvious it's from Castlevania when you see it, it was a boss with a whip.

I think my first "Horror Game" was Super Metroid. I would watch my father play it since I was too young. And when he bet Mother Brain, me and my little sister weren't allowed to watch, but my older sister was ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
I'll be honest, I actually was less fond of Vampire Killer, NOT because I think it's a bad song at all, but because it's not quite as... dark? as the best Castlevania songs are.  It's like, it's not quite as atmospheric as some of it's best entries.  At least the NES versions of the song.

It's pretty much the only thing I felt Simon's Quest did completely better.  So much of the music in that game felt oppressive, which is exactly the way it should be.  :o
snippet.textOriginal:
I'll be honest, I actually was less fond of Vampire Killer, NOT because I think it's a bad song at all, but because it's not quite as... dark? as the best Castlevania songs are.  It's like, it's not quite as atmospheric as some of it's best entries.  At least the NES versions of the song.

It's pretty much the only thing I felt Simon's Quest did completely better.  So much of the music in that game felt oppressive, which is exactly the way it should be.  :o

snippet.textDisplay: My first was also CV, the arcade version thereof in fact. And it was quite terrifying - relentless waves of enemies, precise jumping that required plenty of foresight and good timing, bosses that really put the pressure on you... even to this day there isn't a "scarier" entry in the whole series, and that was one that used bright orange and blue all the time!!
snippet.textOriginal: My first was also CV, the arcade version thereof in fact. And it was quite terrifying - relentless waves of enemies, precise jumping that required plenty of foresight and good timing, bosses that really put the pressure on you... even to this day there isn't a "scarier" entry in the whole series, and that was one that used bright orange and blue all the time!!

snippet.textDisplay: @bsznm Lol, I had thoughts about the same things at one point. Technically, music is only a form of expression so generally in reality there is no standard for quality but a preference of types. I think its kind of a mix of both of your latter statements, because certain types of music are defined by the type of sounds made, and the newer ones might have had poor instrument choice and could use work on the arrangement. Kinda like bramble blast. The new one has a different feel with orchestration
snippet.textOriginal: @bsznm Lol, I had thoughts about the same things at one point. Technically, music is only a form of expression so generally in reality there is no standard for quality but a preference of types. I think its kind of a mix of both of your latter statements, because certain types of music are defined by the type of sounds made, and the newer ones might have had poor instrument choice and could use work on the arrangement. Kinda like bramble blast. The new one has a different feel with orchestration

snippet.textDisplay:
notice how it gets perceptively worse as they arrange it in more powerful sound systems.

is that because the limited instruments in the earlier ones subconsciously lower our standards? or is it because the theme was truly good, but was so tailored to the limited palette that it doesn't work outside of it? or is it just because the later arrangements happen to be poorly executed?

these are the stupid things i think about
snippet.textOriginal:
notice how it gets perceptively worse as they arrange it in more powerful sound systems.

is that because the limited instruments in the earlier ones subconsciously lower our standards? or is it because the theme was truly good, but was so tailored to the limited palette that it doesn't work outside of it? or is it just because the later arrangements happen to be poorly executed?

these are the stupid things i think about

snippet.textDisplay: When I was young and I rented Ocarina of Time for the first time I loved it. But that first dungeon scared the shit out of me when I was 6-10 years old, especially the boss. She gave me nightmares for weeks. So I have to say that Ocarina of Time was the first horror game I have played. Well actually the first game I was ever afraid of. Not really sure if that counts though.

snippet.textDisplay: Lament of Innocence was both my first (as in, the "purest") horror-themed game and my first and still only Castlevania game this far (unfortunately). Even if it's not the best in the series (I can't really tell), I'm happy I finally could try a series I've been so curious about for many years - due to its awesome music. And now I know I'd love the rest of the games too... there's simply no way a Castlevania game could go wrong.
snippet.textOriginal: Lament of Innocence was both my first (as in, the "purest") horror-themed game and my first and still only Castlevania game this far (unfortunately). Even if it's not the best in the series (I can't really tell), I'm happy I finally could try a series I've been so curious about for many years - due to its awesome music. And now I know I'd love the rest of the games too... there's simply no way a Castlevania game could go wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: There are so many fantastic songs from this series, it's mind-blowing.  Gears Go Awry, Iron Blue Intention, Dance of the Holy Man, Bloody Tears, Vampire Killer, Riddle, Forest of Monsters, In Search of a Secret, Within These Castle Walls, Wood Carving Partita, Garden Forgotten By Time, Heart of Fire, Clock Tower, An Empty Tome, Tower of Dolls, Sorrow's Distortion, Prayer, The Tragic Prince, Wandering Ghosts, Prayer of a Tragic Queen, Abandoned Castle... and that's just off the top of my head!!!!
snippet.textOriginal: There are so many fantastic songs from this series, it's mind-blowing.  Gears Go Awry, Iron Blue Intention, Dance of the Holy Man, Bloody Tears, Vampire Killer, Riddle, Forest of Monsters, In Search of a Secret, Within These Castle Walls, Wood Carving Partita, Garden Forgotten By Time, Heart of Fire, Clock Tower, An Empty Tome, Tower of Dolls, Sorrow's Distortion, Prayer, The Tragic Prince, Wandering Ghosts, Prayer of a Tragic Queen, Abandoned Castle... and that's just off the top of my head!!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
For me too, I guess SOTN is on top (must have finished it 20 times at least), with Dracula X following closely behind.
In terms of horror game... maybe Resident Evil 2?
The 1st real scaring moment was walking into a quiet and narrow hallway (that you already crossed once before) only to find a scary motherf***ing... thing... bursting out of the window! and you add like 5 sec to down him or you were dead...
As a kid, I was scared as f***!!!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: This was my first horror game as well (Castlevania NES)  As far as all time fave, it's a tie between Dracula X for the SNES and SOTN for the PS1.  Kinda funny seeing as how Dracula X was the prequel to SOTN storyline wise.  And for Konami to keep it 2D on a system focusing more on 3dD and it being one of the best games of all time (along with the music) it's phenomenal.
snippet.textOriginal: This was my first horror game as well (Castlevania NES)  As far as all time fave, it's a tie between Dracula X for the SNES and SOTN for the PS1.  Kinda funny seeing as how Dracula X was the prequel to SOTN storyline wise.  And for Konami to keep it 2D on a system focusing more on 3dD and it being one of the best games of all time (along with the music) it's phenomenal.

snippet.textDisplay:
Haha! I love how it goes through all of the versions. I haven't been a big Castlevania fan, but i gotta admit this music is pretty awesome, especially the way it evolves.

Scary game... Resident evil 2... I was 3 and my brother was playing with his friends. The beginning came and all the fire was scaring me. People groaning and moaning made it so eerie and his friend died a the beginning. Blood spattered all over the screen and I got so scared I ran to the bathroom and wet myself... lol

snippet.textDisplay: Resident Evil for me. the first one, on the playstation.  My slightly older cousin, my brother, and myself, with nothing but our wits and a strategy guide, and screams and freak-outs, it was one hard, scary, and amazing game!  We were at it for nights on end over the summer, and our titanic trio grew to take on many horror games in that fashion.
snippet.textOriginal: Resident Evil for me. the first one, on the playstation.  My slightly older cousin, my brother, and myself, with nothing but our wits and a strategy guide, and screams and freak-outs, it was one hard, scary, and amazing game!  We were at it for nights on end over the summer, and our titanic trio grew to take on many horror games in that fashion.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's intresting to see that the very best version of Vampire Killer is still the original Castlevania 1 8bit theme. =)

Also i must say VK is right up there with wily 1 theme from mm2, journey to silius title theme and many others, as one of -THE- 8-bit classics that always will be remembered. Granted, many other tunes in the castlevania series are just as good.. but this is the one everyone remembers.

snippet.textDisplay: There are the classic ones and the Metroid-like ones. If you're going for the classics I'd say Super Castlevania 4 is a good choice. If you're going for the Metroidvanias, just don't pick up Order of Ecclesia first. I'd reccomend Aria of Sorrow (for the GBA) or Symphony of the Night (PS, Sega Saturn, PSN and XBOX Live Arcade I think)

snippet.textDisplay: My first horror themed game? Ghosts N' Goblins. NES. This along with and Megaman and Punch Out set me up on my path for breezing through harder games because they were the first things I had to work with. Castlavania was tough but with practice being GNG, it wasn't as hard as it should've been. Great game still though.

snippet.textDisplay:
Favorite Castlevania would be SOTN.. then probably followed by AOS/DOS. Favorite version of Vampire Killer for me would be from Dracula X. Love that one a lot.

First real scary game was Resident Evil Director's Cut PS1 Regular not dual shock. Man that game scared the crap out of me... I can still remember the dog jumping into the window. Man... awesome. Nowdays RE series are mostly action games... sad... Scariest game to date for me would be Silent Hill 2. Now that's epic on its own level.

snippet.textDisplay: Great choice. But in answer to your question ("What better song to represent Castlevania than Vampire Killer?"), I have to say Bloody Tears. Just an awesome track; there have been variations of it into every genre I can imagine. Also, my first "horror" game was SCVIV for the SNES. Also my favourite CV game. I love what you can do with the whip in that game.
snippet.textOriginal: Great choice. But in answer to your question ("What better song to represent Castlevania than Vampire Killer?"), I have to say Bloody Tears. Just an awesome track; there have been variations of it into every genre I can imagine. Also, my first "horror" game was SCVIV for the SNES. Also my favourite CV game. I love what you can do with the whip in that game.

snippet.textDisplay: One of the resident evils was my first Horror themed game. So I guess RE3, REmake, and RE0 are my first ones, since I remember them around the same time, and REmake, specifically the shark part, stands out to me. I watched my brother play, as I was like 7-9, and was too scared to play, and I kinda still am. Not good at RE, cept for 4.

snippet.textDisplay:
Funnily enough, my first horror/action game was also Castlevania IV for the SNES. I must've been around 7, I dont remember exactly. But I still love listening the music from that game to this day, even though my fav of the series is actually SOTN that I first played on the PS1 and now I have it on my 360 :)

I recommend the Dracula battle rock arrange I and II albums for anyone who wants to hear kick-ass heavy metal versions of all these classics!! Those two albums have no equal, IMO.
snippet.textOriginal:
Funnily enough, my first horror/action game was also Castlevania IV for the SNES. I must've been around 7, I dont remember exactly. But I still love listening the music from that game to this day, even though my fav of the series is actually SOTN that I first played on the PS1 and now I have it on my 360 :)

I recommend the Dracula battle rock arrange I and II albums for anyone who wants to hear kick-ass heavy metal versions of all these classics!! Those two albums have no equal, IMO.

snippet.textDisplay:
My first horror themed game would probably be Castlevania 2, I missed the first one. Glad I had Nintendo Power for that one. 

My favorite would be Silent Hill 1 or 2. They're not horror "themed" though. They ARE horror. Resident Evil and Castlevania are horror themed because you don't feel horror while you're playing them. Not usually anyway.
snippet.textOriginal:
My first horror themed game would probably be Castlevania 2, I missed the first one. Glad I had Nintendo Power for that one. 

My favorite would be Silent Hill 1 or 2. They're not horror "themed" though. They ARE horror. Resident Evil and Castlevania are horror themed because you don't feel horror while you're playing them. Not usually anyway.

If they don't count then it goes to either RE2 or Parasite Eve.

snippet.textDisplay:
First horror-themed game I EVER EVER played? Resident Evil.

And my favorite game in the Castlevania series would have to be Symphony of the Night, closely followed by Super Castlevania IV. I'm a sucker for non-linear gameplay, exploration, leveling up and collecting things. 

The Castlevania games for Game Boy Advance are also superb, IMO.
snippet.textOriginal:
First horror-themed game I EVER EVER played? Resident Evil.

And my favorite game in the Castlevania series would have to be Symphony of the Night, closely followed by Super Castlevania IV. I'm a sucker for non-linear gameplay, exploration, leveling up and collecting things. 

The Castlevania games for Game Boy Advance are also superb, IMO.

snippet.textDisplay: Nice montage of the different versions; but you did forget the Circle of the Moon version.
snippet.textOriginal: Nice montage of the different versions; but you did forget the Circle of the Moon version.

snippet.textDisplay: My first was also Castlevania IV.
snippet.textOriginal: My first was also Castlevania IV.

snippet.textDisplay:
I could've sworn I heard a YTP of this song before.

Okay... VGM #700 will be Wizpig. ;)
snippet.textOriginal:
I could've sworn I heard a YTP of this song before.

snippet.textDisplay:
Castlevania IV was the first one of these games I ever played.  

Dawn of Sorrow and Symphony of the Night are probably better objectively, but Castlevania IV had one of the SNES's finest soundtracks and it's just flat fun to play.  I still love it.
snippet.textOriginal:
Castlevania IV was the first one of these games I ever played.  

Dawn of Sorrow and Symphony of the Night are probably better objectively, but Castlevania IV had one of the SNES's finest soundtracks and it's just flat fun to play.  I still love it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Grats on 600!
And for the first horror themed game... dunno if this counts, but Zombies Ate My Neighbors? I've never been big into the horror games haha. Zombies Ate My Neighbors used to give me the creeps, but I played it anyways!

snippet.textDisplay: My favorite Castlevania game? That would have to be a tie between Symphony Of The Night and Order Of Ecclessia. Don't ask why, please. As for most memorable horror game, that title would easily go to Yume Nikki, and not just because of Uboa........DAMN YOU, BIG RED!

snippet.textDisplay: SOTN was my first Castlevania when I downloaded it over XBL two years ago. Since then I've played the 3 GBA games, Super Castlevania 4, and Dawn of Sorrow.

snippet.textDisplay:
Grats on 600 strong, Supra. I've never had the opportunity to play any Castlevania games seriously, unfortunately. 

First horror game? lol Depends, I'm quite averted to the genre. I always thought Goldeneye 007 was really creepy. My most vivid experience with the games though is probably Alone in the Dark (forget which). It was a demo for PS1. Crazy scary.
